fields.description: When trying to access any of my repositories (e.g. http://bitbucket.org/shamiq/introaihw3/ ), the web site keeps trying to load without any resolution. Attempts to pull from the repository also result in the same endless wait. This has been happening since at least 10:50 pm CST, May 10, 2010.
fields.summary: Attempts to access repository do not resolve.

fields.description:
As of a week ago (give or take a month), we've stopped receiving push notification e-mails from bitbucket.

This is on all of our private repo(s).

We changed no settings on bitbucket.  It just stopped working at some point.

We use the e-mail notifications as part of our continuous integration setup, and this is a serious issue for us.  Please advise.
fields.summary: E-mail notifications stopped working (private repo issue?)

fields.description:
We have a large repository with over 300 heads (http://bitbucket.org/mediawiki/root).

However, due to http://mercurial.selenic.com/bts/issue2126 anyway to clone/pull this repository fails. It is difficult to fix this bug without changing the wire protocol, but maybe the HTTP server URL length limit can be pushed to accommodate large multi-head repositories?
fields.summary: hg clone/push/pull fails with HTTP Error 414: Request-URI Too Large

fields.description:
A repository that contains many heads (mine has 318 at the moment) is impossible to pull or push via HTTP. Only SSH method works.

This is a result of the Mercurial bug http://mercurial.selenic.com/bts/issue2126 but can be worked around be increasing URI length limit of the HTTP server.

Repository to try it on:

http://bitbucket.org/mediawiki/root/
fields.summary: hg clone fails with HTTP Error 414: Request-URI Too Large

fields.description:

17 changesets found\\

user: dongsheng\\
password:\\

But push to hg-bfiles no errors.
I'm trying to delete a file in my repo. When I click delete it prompts me for confirmation, I click OK. It then displays the spinner continually. No file is delete if I refresh the page.

Since i'm using bitbucket for personal repositories and work repo's I would like to commit with two different email addresses (personal / gmail email address for personal projects, work email address for work related projects).

It is possible to add X number of email addresses to an account instead of only one?

Cheers! :)

Tried to create *family98029* repository in dev98029 account, but it failed.  Apparently the *family98029* is partly there, and partly not, because when I tried to create again, I got error message.

It would be nice, if you use … (...) at the end of chopped issue titles in the lists views.

For example, look at issue BCLOUD-1 at this list:\\
http://bitbucket.org/kimmov/winmerge-web/issues

The title is shown as following:\\\
*CreateMasterPotFile.py creates POT file with Windows EO*

but is in real:\\\
*CreateMasterPotFile.py creates POT file with Windows EOL*

I first thougt, I made a typo but then notice, that you chop the title for the list. This is ok, but it would be nicer, if you add … at the end in this case:\\\
*CreateMasterPotFile.py creates POT file with Windows EO...*

So you see at the first look, that the title is chopped! :)

Greetings,\\
Tim Gerundt
fields.summary: Use … if you chop issue titles in list views (BB-814)

I seem to have lost access to my private repository quite suddenly. can see the overview of my project but when I try to view any other items I only see a message saying I don't have permission.

Go to http://www.bitbucket.org/kevin.howerton/cujo/wiki/Home and try to login from the menubar via OpenID.

=== Actual result

All i get is the login screen with - what it seems to be - a broken image between the two login-boxes.

There, the login box to the left works, the OpenID box to the right doesn't. It seems to just refresh that page.

When logging in from the frontpage's login box in the top right corner via OpenID, everything works.

This occurred in one of my private repos, I don't have tested it explicitly, but I think this is a common problem.

Steps :

# Choose to strip a changeset on a branch which does not include the "tip".
# Go to Admin (click Repo management)
# Type the changeset number or hashid to the text box and submit it.
# Next screen will show the preview of changesets which are going to be stripped. There are more changesets than these should be there!
# Verify the action with the password.
# Look at the result ... the action behaves correctly, by stripping the appropriate changesets. So the problem is on step 4. (The preview of stripped changesets is buggy)

I hope this is helpful ;)
fields.summary: Preview of strip command is problematic

* [ [ Existent Page ] ] = //Normal link style//

Most Wikis do it this way...

Thank you very much!

Tim Gerundt

Get source -link should  always point to the HEAD. not the current HEAD. This way users could share a link which will always contain the newest version of the software in tarball.

Take example from Github.

This would be especially great with Python projects. You could then always install the newest version with easy_install.

eg.

{{{\\
$ easy_install http://bitbucket.org/user/app/get/head.tar.bz2\\
}}}
fields.summary: Get source -link should point always point to the HEAD

fields.description:
Google apps supports openid for hosted domains, but requires some extra extensions to the standard openid protocol. Our company is moving to google apps, and we'd like to use openid for Bitbucket authentication.

Currently if we enter the openid URL: https://www.google.com/accounts/o8/site-xrds?hd=example.com

Bitbucket returns a 404 response received error. But if you try the same URL with an example OpenId implementation like http://www.puffypoodles.com/ it works as expected.

Anything you can do on your end?\\
Here is my repository https://becomplete@bitbucket.org/ChadSmall/product-compare/

Thanks,\\
Jerry

The first comma should be a semicolon, or maybe a period.

When editing *[[http://bitbucket.org/gatoatigrado/sketch-frontend/wiki/Installation?rev=47ac6586dc1e|this]]* page, I get a message about a Wiki macro error... I thought you might want to take a look.

Nicholas
fields.summary: "Wiki macro error: 'NoneType' object has no attribute 'endswith'"

fields.description:
When forking a project (to work on), I'm confused about why it gives such a hard sounding warning.

Is it that Hg branches are expensive (in disk storage?).  Maybe the warning should be changed to something more like:

"FORKING is for when you want to have your own copy to work on and modify.  If you just want to change a local copy, and have no intentions of pushing changes back upstream, you don't need to fork".

Or some other text about _how to make the decision_ whether or not to fork.

Thanks for clarification!
fields.summary: Why does bitbucket warn about forks? (BB-806)

fields.description:
For people who are not using Hg, it seems to be a little awkward to get download a tarball (or zip) of the source for a project.

In "get source", when clicked on, it does an action that downloads it for you.  I got sick of this when using Sourceforge!  The problem is that it makes it hard to use {{wget}} and friends to download source.   Not every server has a web browser!

(As a side note... the .gz and bz2 are misleading in that that the downloaded items are really .tar.gz and .tar.bz2... correcting that could save some confusion).

Thanks for the great product!

Gregg
fields.summary: "get source" goes to actions, not links

fields.description: Wrong committer name is displayed - author name from commit information (e.g. "ivan") instead of the authenticated user who has really performed the commit (e.g. "imartyushev"). This is rather confusing: instead of my team member "Ivan Martyushev / imartyushev", I see some unknown person "Iván Valdés / ivan" with a link to his profile which displays imartyushev's commits. And all that because my teammate's local login is "ivan" and Eclipse thinks that author name should also be "ivan".

On my project:  http://bitbucket.org/gregglind/python-whython3k,\\
I get 500s when trying "edit" the wiki.

When trying to access files in private repositories, Bitbucket fails to send a HTTP 401 with a WWW-Authenticate header:

{{{\\
$ curl -I http://bitbucket.org/<privaterepo>/raw/tip/<path>\\
HTTP/1.1 403 FORBIDDEN\\
Date: Wed, 31 Mar 2010 18:33:12 GMT\\
Server: nginx/0.7.62\\
Content-Type: text/html; charset=utf-8\\
Vary: Cookie,Accept-Encoding\\
}}}

(I've left the actual repo and path out since they're private; contact me privately and I'd be happy to share the real details.)

This isn't just wrong from an HTTP standpoint; well-formed HTTP clients -- and Python's urllib2, in particular -- won't send authentication information unless challenged with an HTTP 401:

{{{

bq. bq. bq. import urllib2\\
passman = urllib2.HTTPPasswordMgrWithDefaultRealm()\\
passman.add_password(None, 'http://bitbucket.org/', 'jacobian', '<password>')\\
authhandler = urllib2.HTTPBasicAuthHandler(passman)\\
opener = urllib2.build_opener(authhandler)\\
f = opener.open('http://bitbucket.org/<repo>/raw/tip/<path>')\\
...\\
HTTPError: HTTP Error 403: FORBIDDEN\\
}}}




This also fails if you use a basic {{{HTTPPasswordMgr}}} and specify the realm manually.

I discovered this when trying to use Review Board (1.5 beta 2) with a private Bitbucket repository. Review Board uses urllib2 in a manner nearly exactly like the above (see http://github.com/reviewboard/reviewboard/blob/master/reviewboard/scmtools/hg.py#L105).

I'm going to file this same bug against Review Board in a moment, and it probably won't be _too_ hard to hack around Bitbucket's behavior and make Review Board work. But it is indeed a Bitbucket bug: Bitbucket should be sending a HTTP 401 response.
fields.summary: bitbucket doesn't properly send HTTP 401 responses header on private repository requests (BB-805)

Hi,

I create a patch queue with a name of, say "fubar", and accidentially commit up the wrong stuff, I try to delete the patch queue and it works.

However, I can't reuse the name "fubar" for the patch queue since BB seems to think that this repo is still alive.

I have to delete my main repo, recreate it, then go and create a new patch queue again...

-=david=-
fields.summary: Patch Queues - Delete and Reuse Errors (BB-804)

fields.description: The POST service is nice and reasonable, but Hudson wants to have a GET request on a URL to trigger builds and doesn't accept a POST request at that same URL.  So adding a GET service would be helpful.

//Edit:// It should be unnecessary to remember a password when I am using OpenID.

I'm looking for a way to delete a repository without the burden of having a password to remember for bitbucket. A satisfactory solution would be to have a one-time verification password sent as part of a deletion request. Alternatively a verification email with a link I would need to follow.

Specifically: Suggesting a password reset will not solve this issue.

----
//Original text://

I want to delete a repository. It requires me to enter my password for verification. Because I have only used OpenID for login, I do not have a password to enter here.

I found a related issue: <<issue 1803>>

The resolution here seems to be "acquire a password". I don't want one, and that's why I chose to use OpenID in the first place.
fields.summary: OpenID, but password is required for repository deletion (BB-489)

Any ideas?

http://www.google.com/buzz/ianbicking/624rGftHt5Q/Im-starting-to-feel-a-bit-worried-about-the

I don't feel like recording all the bugs I spot. It generally just feels like a slightly flakier experience then GitHub is. That's ASIDE from the fact that GitHub is now much more feature rich.
fields.summary: BitBucket is not as good as GitHub (not even close anymore)

fields.description:
Sometimes new events in newsfeed (commits, comments, etc) are shown, and after page refresh they aren't. Events that happen 1 hour ago can be visible but events 5 hours-old can be invisible and after page refresh things may change again: some 5 hours-old events becomes visible, recent updates become invisible.

This can lead to situation in which it is easy to miss some updates. Consider the following scenario: there are a lot of recent updates that are visible and a few not-so-recent updates that are invisible. Even if not-so-recent updates will become visible I won't see them on first pages so it's easy to miss some updates. That's why the newsfeed becomes less useful after the bitbucket infrastructure changes: one can't rely on it to have recent information. I think it should be fixed regardless of performance issues because the main purpose of newsfeed is to stay in touch with followed repositories and tickets and that becomes hard to achieve with this bug.

There's a link to open and closed issues in the drop-down for Issues, but none to show issues marked as on-hold.  Only "all issues" shows those issues.

It also seems reasonable to have them as open issues, just sorted at the bottom.
fields.summary: No link to query on-hold issues

fields.description: I wish pull requests were issues, not notifications (which I find hard to keep track of).  Also it allows open discussion of the pull request.  Ideally the issue would be closed automatically once the pull was applied.

am i doing something wrong, or is this really a strange bug?

btw - the "Inbox (1)" is showed in all the repository's tabs, so not just on the wiki site, but at none of the other sites (eg. this reporting-site)

greetz

In my workflow it would help me a great deal if I could add new versions via the API. For instance, If I have tagged a new version of my software, I could simply implement a {{{post-outgoing}}} hook to take care of this automatically.

Proposed endpoints:

*GET /repositories/:username/:repo_slug/versions/*\\
Gets all versions of a single single repository

*POST /repositories/:username/:repo_slug/versions/*\\
Creates a new version

*PUT /repositories/:username/:repo_slug/versions/*\\
Updates an existing version.

*DELETE /repositories/:username/:repo_slug/versions/*\\
Deletes an existing version.

I now get the following:

{{{\\
#!bash

hg push\\
running ssh hg@bitbucket.org "hg -R blackpaw/konfigsync/ serve --stdio"\\
pushing to ssh://hg@bitbucket.org/blackpaw/konfigsync/\\
searching for changes\\
1 changesets found\\
remote: abort: journal already exists - run hg recover!\\
abort: unexpected response: empty string

}}}

I've run hg recover locally but that has no effect

$ hg clone https://melnichek@bitbucket.org/melnichek/omim/\\

password:\\

requesting all changes\\

}}}
